All immovable property to be liable to local cess. From and after the commencement of this Act in any district or part of a district, all immovable property situate therein, except as otherwise in section 2(2) provided, shall be liable to the payment of local cess.

concepts.interpretation: Creates the charge for local cess on all immovable property including mines.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ction. What is crucial and of sole relevance are the words and the width and scope of the charging provision and if the appellants are within it matte

concepts.unlisted_description: Imposition of local cess on immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: Cess how to be assessed.-The local cess shall be assessed on the annual value of land and until provision to the contrary is made by the Central Legislature on the annual net profits from mines and quarries, other than notified mines and from tramways, railways and other immovable property, ascertained respectively as in this Act prescribed...

concepts.interpretation: Cess on annual net profits from mines even where ore is not sold but utilised in manufacturing, determined by disintegrating overall profits from sale of end products.

anchor.surface_text: Notice to return profits.- (1) On the commencement of this Act in any district, and thereafter before the close of each year, the Collector of the district shall cause a notice to be served upon the owner, chief agent, manager or occupier of every mine or quarry other than a notified mine...

anchor.surface_text: 72A. Penalty for omitting to make a return.- Any owner, chief agent, manager or occupier who, without sufficient cause being shown to the satisfaction of the Collector, refuses or omits to lodge the required return...

concepts.unlisted_description: Penalty for failure to furnish return of profits.

anchor.surface_text: When property lies in different districts.Whenever any property assessable under this Chapter lies in two or more districts, the notice to furnish a return under section 72 shall be served...

concepts.unlisted_description: Assessment when property in multiple districts.

anchor.surface_text: When a property is partly in and partly outside Bengal.-Whenever any property assessable under this Chapter lies partly within and partly outside the territories administered by the Lieutenant-Governor of Bengal...

concepts.unlisted_description: Return for property partly inside/outside Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: If return not furnished or incorrect, Collector to make valuation.-If such return be not furnished within the period of two months from the date on which such notice was served...

Valuation on value of property.-If such Collector be unable to ascertain the annual net profits... he may... ascertain and determine the value of such property, and shall thereupon determine six per cent on such value to be the annual net profits thereon...

issues.text: whether the three appellants could be said to have derived annual net profits from the mines when the ore mined by them is not sold as such but is utilised for the production of finished products which the appellants sell.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised for decision is whether the three appellants could be said to have derived annual net profits from the mines when the ore mined by them is not sold as such but is utilised for the production of finished products which the appellants sell.

issues.text: whether a person could in law be said to derive profit from a mine when the ore extracted is not sold by him as such but is utilised by him for the purpose of manufacturing a finished product which he sells.

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen from the above narration that the question for decision is whether a person could in law be said to derive profit from a mine when the ore extracted is not sold by him as such but is utilised by him for the purpose of manufacturing a finished product which he sells.

issues.text: whether the total profits derived from an integrated business cannot be disintegrated and apportioned between the different activities unless the relevant statute makes specific provision for such purpose.

anchor.surface_text: it hinges on the acceptance of the proposition that no profit accrues from a mine to an owner unless the ore extracted is sold by him to a third person and the somewhat related proposition that where a person carries on a multiple but nonetheless an integrated activity that produces an entire profit, the total profits derived by him cannot be disintegrated and apportioned between the different activities unless the relevant statute under which the tax is imposed makes specific provision for such purpose.

issues.text: whether it was s. 5 of the Act which created the charge and imposed the liability and that s. 6 and the other related provision in s. 72 merely provided the yardstick or the measure of that charge.

anchor.surface_text: His submission was that it was s. 5 of the Act which created the charge and imposed the liability and that s. 6 and the other related provision in s. 72 merely provided the yardstick or the measure of that charge and that as the mine was immovable property within the district it was subject to the cess at the rates specified in ss. 5 & 6.

issues.text: whether the Act was defective in that it did not provide any specific machinery for the type of cases now on hand and that owing to this lack of machinery there could be no imposition of the charge.

anchor.surface_text: It was further submitted to us that the Act was defective in that it did not provide any specific machinery for the type of cases now on hand and that owing to this lack of machinery there could be no imposition of the charge.

issues.text: whether there could in law be a profit or a net profit being derived when the mined ore is utilised by a mine-owner in his factory.

anchor.surface_text: because, if it is possible to conceive in law of a profit or a net profit being derived when the mined ore is utilised by a mine-owner in his factory, neither in logic nor on principle is there any difficulty in there being an annual net profit, particularly seeing that the operation of mining is a continuous process extending for years together.

arguments.claim: Cess under s.6 is levied on annual net profits derived from the mine, which requires sale of extracted ore to a third party as profit emerges only from sale exceeding extraction cost.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6, which has to be read with s. 72, the tax imposed by the Act is number a tax on the mine as a species of immovable property, but on the annual net profits derived from the mine. In order that a person may derive profit from a mine, the mine must be worked and the ore extracted, but even that by itself is insufficient. The extraction of the ore involves expenditure andprofits companyld be said to be derived from the mine only when the extracted ore is sold and the amount realised by the sale of the ore is in excess of the companyt of extracting the ore. A sale of the ore is thus an essential ingredient or a sine qua

arguments.court_reasoning: Profit can be derived without direct sale via disintegration of profits from integrated activities; sale of end product embeds mine profit.

arguments.claim: Appellants' business is a single integrated undertaking; cannot postulate separate mining and manufacturing businesses or fictional sale of ore from one to the other.

anchor.surface_text: Where, however, the ore extracted is number sold but is used by the owner in the production of other finished products there is numberquestion of the owner of the ore realising a profit from the mine. In these of an assessee like the appellants the business of winning the ore and of companyverting the ore won into a finished product is number by any means to be companyceived of as made up of two distinct businesses companyducted by them but only as a single integrated undertaking for the production of steel and steel products. Unless one companyld postulate first that the business of winning the ore was a separate business from that of Converting the ore won into steel, and secondly, companyld nationally treat the won ore as having been sold by the first business to the second, it would number be possible to companyceive of any profit being derived from the working of the mine.

holdings.text: where activities other than mere winning the ore are carried on by an assessee and there is a transaction of sale of the ultimate product and the profit, if any derived from the working of the mine is, so to speak, embedded in the final realisation, a profit may accrue to the assessee from the mining operation which can be disintegrated and ascertained and a tax levied thereon.

anchor.surface_text: We have already held on a construction of ss. 5, 6 and 72 that where activities other than mere winning the ore are carried on by an assessee and there is a transaction of sale of the ultimate product and the profit, if any derived from the working of the mine is, so to speak, embedded in the final realisation, a profit may accrue to the assessee from the mining operation which can be disintegrated and ascertained and a tax levied thereon.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Construction of ss.5,6,72 permits profit from mining embedded in end-product sale profits via disintegration; factual benefit realized without self-sale.

holdings.text: the principle of apportionment resting on the disintegration of the ultimate profits realised by the assessee is implicit in a provision like that in s. 6 of the Act under which the profit derived from an initial activity is brought to charge where further activities are undertaken by an assessee with reference to the ore won and a profit is realised by the sale of the end product.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the principle of apportionment resting on the disintegration of the ultimate profits realised by the assessee is implicit in a provision like that in s. 6 of the Act under which the profit derived from an initial activity is brought to charge where further activities are undertaken by an assessee with reference to the ore won and a profit is realised by the sale of the end product.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.6 implicitly requires apportionment for taxing initial mining profit in integrated operations; analogous to Income Tax rules for partial agricultural/business income.

holdings.text: It matters little whether in technical language the charging section is S. 5 or ss. 5, 6 and 72 read together. When once it is conceded, as it must be, that in the case of a mine there is no liability to pay the tax unless the mine were worked and the working produced a profit

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the submission provides no answer to the problem before us. It matters little whether in technical language the charging section is S. 5 or ss. 5, 6 and 72 read together. When once it is conceded, as it must be, that in the case of a mine there is no liability to pay the tax unless the mine were worked and the working produced a profit,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Whether s.5 or ss.5-6-72 charge, liability requires actual profit from working mine; respondent's measure-only view insufficient.

holdings.text: We do not consider that there is force in this argument.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that there is force in this argument. We have already held on a construction of ss. 5, 6 and 72 that where activities other than mere winning the ore are carried on by an assessee and there is a transaction of sale of the ultimate product and the profit, if any derived from the working of the mine is, so to speak, embedded in the final realisation,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ss.72-76 provide machinery (returns, inquiry, fallback 6% value); sufficient for captive consumption cases.

holdings.text: But that is not the position here.

anchor.surface_text: But that is not the position here. Though the mined ore was not itself the subject of a sale, it was converted into a commodity which was the subject of a sale. The question, therefore, arises whether when a sale or a commercial transaction which might result in a profit takes place not of the commodity itself but of something into which it is transformed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Kikabhai (stock withdrawal no sale) as here ore transformed and end-product sold, allowing profit attribution without self-trade.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

precedents.citation: Styles v. The New York Lift, Insurance Company  1

anchor.surface_text: the House of Lords in Styles v. The New York Lift, Insurance Company  1  that numberone can make a profit out of himself. He also referred us to the following passage in the judgment of. Rowlatt, J., in Thomas v. Richard Evans Co., Ltd.  2  It is true to say a person cannot make a profit out of himself, if what is meant is that he may provide himself with something at a lesser companyt than that at which he companyld buy it, or if he does something for himself instead of employing somebody to do it. He saves money in those circumstances, but he does number make a profit.

precedents.case_name: Styles v New York Life Insurance Company
precedents.cited_proposition: no one can make a profit out of himself

He saves money in those circumstances, but he does number make a profit. He further invited our attention to Ostime v. Pontypridd  3  and to the passage in the speech of Viscount Simon in the House of Lords The identity of the source with the recipient prevents any question of profits arising.

precedents.cited_holding: It is true to say a person cannot make a profit out of himself...

anchor.surface_text: He further invited our attention to Ostime v. Pontypridd  3  and to the passage in the speech of Viscount Simon in the House of Lords The identity of the source with the recipient prevents any question of profits arising. His next submission was that this principle had been accepted by this Court in Kikabhai Premchand v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay  4  and that  1   1889  2 T. C. 460.

precedents.cited_proposition: identity of the source with the recipient prevents any question of profits arising

precedents.case_name: Kikabhai Premchand v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: principle that a person cannot make a profit out of himself applies

anchor.surface_text: it has been held by the House of Lords in Sharkey v. Wernher  1  that the general proposition that numberone companyld trade with himself and make in its true sense or meaning taxable profits by dealing with himself is number universally true and, that there are situations in which a man companyld be said to make a profit 1 out of the companysumption of his own goods.

precedents.cited_proposition: a person can make taxable profit out of consumption of own goods in some situations

anchor.surface_text: However, as the principle underlying the decision of this Court in Kikabhai Premchands case  2  runs companynter to the decision of the House of Lords in Sharkey v. Wernher  1  vide Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1, Bombay v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka  3  we are bound to proceed on the basis that on facts similar to those in Kikabhais case    the principle applies and negatives the idea of a taxable profit emerging.

precedents.case_name: Kikabhai Premchand v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: no taxable profit from transfer to self

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1, Bombay v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka  3

anchor.surface_text: vide Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1, Bombay v. Bai Shirinbai K. Kooka  3  we are bound to proceed on the basis that on facts similar to those in Kikabhais case    the principle applies and negatives the idea of a taxable profit emerging. It is, therefore, necessary to examine the precise scope of the decision in Kikabhais case  2 .

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay v Bai Shirinbai K Kooka

precedents.citation: Doors Tea Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax West Bengal 2

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection the learned Attorney-General referred us to the decision of this Court in Doors Tea Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax West Bengal 2  . The question raised for decision was whether the value of bamboos, fuel timber etc. grown by an assessee, but which were utilised by him- for the purposes of his tea business companyld be taken into account in companyputing his income, profits and gains for the purposes of the Bengal Agricultural Income Tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Doors Tea Co Ltd v Commissioner of Agricultural Income Tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: value of items grown and used in business is income

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai, Co. Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: For the position that there companyld be a disinter gration of profits for ascertaining the quantum, if any attributable to one of the related and companystituent activities, the learned Counsel for the respondent placed reliance particularly on two decisions of this Court Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai, Co. Bombay 1 , and Anglo- French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras  2 , where the Court effected an apportionment of the income for the purpose of levying income-tax.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay v Ahmedbhai Umarbhai & Co Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: apportionment of income between connected activities

precedents.citation: Anglo- French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras  2

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bombay v. Ahmedbhai Umarbhai, Co. Bombay 1 , and Anglo- French Textile Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras  2 , where the Court effected an apportionment of the income for the purpose of levying income-tax. It is unnecessary to go into the details of those decisions because, as was companyrectly pointed out by the learned Attorney-General, the Court was companycerned in them number with the general principle of apportionability of the incomes, profits or gains accruing from companynected activities but with the interpretation of the specific provisions of the Excess Profits Act, 1940, and the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

precedents.case_name: Anglo French Textile Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: apportionment of income between connected activities

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Diwan Bahadur S. L. Mathias 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Diwan Bahadur S. L. Mathias 1  where Sir George Rankin stated But the green companyfee itself cannot be regarded as income, profits or gains within the meaning of the Act- it is grown for purposes of sale and in order that profit may be earned. The business operations cannot be arbitrarily cut into two portions, but must be regarded as a whole.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v Diwan Bahadur S L Mathias
precedents.cited_proposition: business operations cannot be arbitrarily cut into portions
precedents.cited_holding: the green coffee itself cannot be regarded as income... must be regarded as a whole

anchor.surface_text: In support of this reposition reliance was placed on the well- known decision of the House of Lords in Colquboun v. Brooks  1 . We do number companysider that there is force in this argument. We have already held on a companystruction of ss. 5, 6 and 72 that where activities other than mere winning the ore are carried on by an assessee and there is a transaction of sale of the ultimate product and the profit, if any derived from the working of the mine is, so to speak, embedded in the final realisation, a profit may accrue to the assessee from the mining operation which can be disintegrated and ascertained and a tax levee thereon.

precedents.cited_proposition: taxing statute requires specific machinery for assessment

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Kooka  1

anchor.surface_text: This was precisely the principle of companymercial accountancy on which the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Kooka  1  rests. It is in the same ratio that underlies r. 23 of the Income tax Rules to which we shall advert later.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v Kooka
precedents.cited_proposition: dichotomy for apportionment in commercial accountancy

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the submission provides no answer to the problem before us. It matters little whether in technical language the charging section is S. 5 or ss. 5, 6 and 72 read together. When once it is conceded, as it must be, that in the case of a mine there is no liability to pay the tax unless the mine were worked and the working produced a profit,
The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider that there is force in this argument. We have already held on a construction of ss. 5, 6 and 72 that where activities other than mere winning the ore are carried on by an assessee and there is a transaction of sale of the ultimate product and the profit, if any derived from the working of the mine is, so to speak, embedded in the final realisation,

edges.explanation: 'But that is not the position here' rejects strict no profit from self, supporting the concept's distinction.

anchor.surface_text: But that is not the position here. Though the mined ore was not itself the subject of a sale, it was converted into a commodity which was the subject of a sale. The question, therefore, arises whether when a sale or a commercial transaction which might result in a profit takes place not of the commodity itself but of something into which it is transformed,
The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
